II. Purpose of Addendum
The facility has requested to change the program type being served under the
Riebel program. The facility has requested to change the Riebel program to be a
transitional based programming serving Unaccompanied Children (UC) in long
term foster care placed through the Office of Refugee Resettlement. The facility
has requested for the Riebel program to have the same terms and capacity but
changed to a non-secure setting.
III. Methodology
02/17/2022- Inspection Completed from Fire Inspector clearing the door that will
locked to separate the program from the programming is approved by fire code.
08/16/2022- Application Received- Request to change the Riebel program to service
the Unaccompanied Children in long term foster care placed through the Office of
Refugee Resettlement and change to non-secure setting.
08/30/2022- Contact- Face to Face- Consultant and Area Manager met with Chief
Administrator and Licensee Designee to speak about the requested to plan to
change the Riebel program. Walk through was completed.
09/16/2022- Documentation Received- Finalized Policies and Job Descriptions
reviewed and approved by licensing rules.
09/21/2022- Inspection Completed- On-site- Riebel program toured
10/04/2022- Documentation Received- Finalized Program Statement
IV. Description of Findings and Conclusions
Riebel program is an already approved licensed unit under the Kentwood license
for 13 male youth. The facility has requested the population type they serve be
changed but remain for a capacity of 13 male youth. The facility requested the
change to be from a secure setting to a non-secure setting.
Physical Description of Facility
Riebel unit is located in a well maintained and clean brick building. Upon entering
the main door there is a small area to area leading up to the second door that
leads into the main access of the home. Upon entering the unit there is a large
milieu area where there are tables for youth to use for mealtimes and activities.
The living area is spacious and provides for good staff eyes on supervision. There
is a community bathroom in the milieu area that youth will have access to that
includes a single toilet and sink. There is a kitchen off the side of the milieu area
where there is working cooking appliance and refrigerator. Within the main area
there is one door that is locked with a blocked-out window that connects this unit
to the other units on the Kentwood license. This change had been approved by the
Fire Inspector and allows the Riebel UC youth to be separated from other youth
2

populations under this license. There is another door in the main milieu area
allows the youth to exit to the outside of the building. Within this unit there is two
living hallways. Each hallway has its own door to access from the milieu that is
unlocked so youth have access to their hallways. There is a bathroom located
within each hallway that has a shower inside for youth to access. There are 11
bedrooms located on this unit that allows for space for the licensed 13 male youth.
All doors within the facility are locked from the outside so that youth can exit freely.
There is an emergency exit located within the bedroom hallways. The unit also
includes a staff office where medications, sharps, and other items the youth
cannot have access to will be locked.
Program Description
The Riebel program is a transitional based programing servicing Unaccompanied
Children (UC) in long term foster care placed through the Office of Refugee
Resettlement (ORR) under DHHS. The program services male youth ages 12-17
who are unaccompanied minors. The program is equipped to serve clients who
have experienced violence and trauma. The population served within this program
will meet ORR eligibly requirements depended on the availability of staffing and
capacity.
The Riebel program offers open residential treatment programing with adequate
supervision including 1:6 ration staff to client ratio at all times and video monitoring
with the program. Staff within this program are trained to provide care for clients
that is both culturally and linguistically responsive. The program is secure from
ingress but is open to egress with no locks on bedrooms inside the facility.
Clients are provided for their educational needs through an appropriate community
school setting best fit and are provided with medical services. The program
emphasis Trauma Informed Treatment that focuses on understanding the
neurological, biological, psychological, and social effects of trauma and the
prevalence of these experiences in the refugee population. Clients are also
provided with activity therapy to incorporate a variety of intervention to build
healthy leisure skill development, including experiential assertiveness and self-
esteem therapy. Age-appropriate skills for independent living are taught in activity-
based individual and group programming. Youth are given the option to engage in
spiritual activities and in supervised community activities. Other services
individually provided under the program include individual and group therapy, case
management, educational planning services, life skills training, independent living
training, optional faith-based activity, wellness and activity center access, and
medical/nursing 24 hour on call
Discharge planning begins at admission and continues throughout care,
transitioning to aftercare services at discharge. Every effort is made to identify and
secure necessary follow-up services for youth in anticipation of discharge from
residential treatment. Program clinician and case manager will continue to be
3

available for phone consultation during normal business hours after a youth has
been discharged for a period of at least 30 days to ensure successful transition.
V. Recommendation
I recommend that the Riebel program have an approved change to be the Riebel
UC program and for the program to be approved to be non-secure under the
Kentwood license.
